item.title: The Story Behind DeSantis’s Migrant Flights to Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: Asylum seekers in Texas were recruited for the flights by a woman who appeared to be a former Army counterintelligence agent. “We were tricked,” one migrant said.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval, Miriam Jordan, Patricia Mazzei and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Matthew Busch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of men from Venezuela outside the Migrant Resource Center in San Antonio on Sept. 15.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Hunt Demoralized Russian Stragglers in Seized City
item.description: A major Russian newspaper said the Russian troops, facing defeat in Lyman, had fled with “empty eyes” after barely escaping with their lives.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank near a recaptured area north of Lyman in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Nord Stream Pipelines Have Stopped Leaking After Earlier Damage
item.description: Both European and Russian leaders have said that ruptures discovered undersea were an act of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Danish Defence Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gas leaks were discovered on Nord Stream pipelines in the Baltic Sea last week.

item.title: Indonesian Soccer Stadium Deaths Prompt Focus on Police
item.description: Witnesses said officers fired tear gas indiscriminately into the stands, causing a stampede that led to at least 125 deaths.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Police officers firing tear gas into crowds at Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘I Did All I Could’: As Floodwaters Rose, She Fought to Save Her Disabled Brothers
item.description: Darcy Bishop for decades has cared for her two brothers, who have cerebral palsy. Hurricane Ian was her biggest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Corina Knoll
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Darcy Bishop cleaned up her home after it flooded from Hurricane Ian in Naples, Fla.

item.title: On Sanibel Island, a Search for Stranded Residents Slogs On
item.description: About 200 households did not leave ahead of Hurricane Ian. Rescue teams are tracking down the stranded and evacuating them — if they are willing.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Johnny Milano
item.media:description: A neighbor watched as the Stasi family evacuated Sanibel, Fla.

item.title: The Challenges of Dating With Chronic Illness
item.description: Deciding if and how to share health information can leave daters on a tightrope between vulnerability and vigilance.
item.dc:creator: Fortesa Latifi
item.media:credit: Peter Garritano for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Joseph Kibler, 33, started online dating, he experimented with how best to share information about his health.

item.title: The Racial Divide Herschel Walker Couldn’t Outrun
item.description: As a teenage football prodigy, Mr. Walker was pressed to join a fight for civil rights in his hometown. His decision echoes decades later.
item.dc:creator: John Branch
item.media:description: Herschel Walker in 1979, when he was a high school football star, near the Johnson County Courthouse in Wrightsville, Ga., his hometown.

item.title: As New Term Starts, Supreme Court Is Poised to Resume Rightward Push
item.description: The justices return to the bench on Monday to start a term that will include major cases on affirmative action, voting and discrimination against gay couples. Several will take on questions about race.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: As president, Donald J. Trump appointed three justices to the Supreme Court, including Amy Coney Barrett.

item.title: The Supreme Court’s Business Docket
item.description: Upcoming Supreme Court cases could have big implications for businesses.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in August.

item.title: Anti-Vaccine Parents Go From Welcome to Ostracized in Marin County
item.description: The wealthy California county just north of San Francisco has one of the nation’s highest Covid-19 vaccination rates after years of being known for parents who opposed shots for childhood diseases.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:description: Karen Casas, 4, of Marin County receiving her first Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: This Hearty Bean Soup Gets Only Better With Time
item.description: Packed with squash and greens, it anchors a menu from David Tanis that’s perfectly autumnal and best made in advance.
item.dc:creator: David Tanis
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.
item.media:description: Delicious out of the pot, this fall vegetable soup benefits from sitting.

item.title: America Has a Ginni Thomas Problem
item.description: Clarence and Ginni Thomas are Mr. and Mrs. Mutiny.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: The Supreme Court Isn’t Listening, and It’s No Secret Why
item.description: A court that does not keep the public’s trust cannot perform its critical role in American government.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times

item.title: My First Yom Kippur in Exile
item.description: When it became clear that Vladimir Putin would require me to support his war in Ukraine, I had to leave.
item.dc:creator: Pinchas Goldschmidt

item.title: How Private High Schools Keep the College Pay-to-Win Game Going
item.description: And it can be yours for just four yearly payments of $50,000!
item.dc:creator: Sophie Callcott

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol

item.title: I Make Video Games. I Won’t Let My Daughters Play Them.
item.description: Parents aren’t doing enough to protect their kids from gaming addiction.
item.dc:creator: William Siu

item.title: There Is a Tax That Could Help With Inflation
item.description: The case for a progressive levy on consumption.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: Why the Music of Rich Mullins Endures, 25 Years After His Death
item.description: The Christian singer-songwriter, who died at age 41 in a car crash, has a legacy that lives on.
item.dc:creator: Tish Harrison Warren

item.title: Democrats in Congress Point Fingers at Their Leaders Over Stock Trading Ban
item.description: The perception that lawmakers are cashing in on their offices has fueled cynicism among voters. Some politicians want to take the current limits further.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Abigail Spanberger has criticized fellow Democrats for declining to allow a vote on her proposal to limit lawmakers’ ability to trade individual stocks.

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Safe Space That Became a Viral Nightmare’
item.description: An argument at Arizona State’s multicultural center spiraled into a disaster for everyone involved. Who was to blame?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Viren, Aaron Esposito, Jack D’Isidoro, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Ted Blaisdell
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Sarra Tekola, Miriam Araya, Mastaani Qureshi and Chase Beckerman.

item.title: Billion-dollar disasters
item.description: Hurricane Ian is all but certain to join a growing list of very costly storms.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: San Carlos Island in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., on Thursday.

item.title: Did Your Home Security Camera Document Hurricane Ian?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian on Thursday in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

item.title: How the U.K. Finance Minister Came to Ignore Finance Experts
item.description: Kwasi Kwarteng, the chancellor of the Exchequer, faces widespread anger over the tax cuts he and Liz Truss have pushed, but their history of dismissing the economic establishment goes back years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a series of tax cuts that sent the markets spiraling.

item.title: In Quebec, the Independence Movement Gives Way to a New Nationalism
item.description: In Monday’s election, residents of a town that was once a stronghold of the independence movement are expected to back the province’s popular premier, who has embraced a nationalism based on French Québécois identity.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign that reads, “Yes, keeping the flame alive” in French adorned a house in L’Assomption, Quebec.

item.title: What to Know About the 2022 Nobel Prizes
item.description: The Nobel Prizes will be announced beginning Monday.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: An official Nobel Peace Prize gold medal at the Nobel Peace Center in Oslo last year.

item.title: Eliud Kipchoge Had an Unexpected Hand in His Record-Setting Runs
item.description: Eliud Kipchoge, the world’s greatest marathoner, has an unlikely partner in his world-record-setting marathon runs: a course volunteer who is responsible for handing him nutrition.
item.dc:creator: Austin Meyer
item.media:description: “Never has so much fuss been made about a man giving a drink to another man,” a commentator on live television said.

item.title: F.D.A. Moves to Change ‘Healthy’ Food Definition
item.description: Salmon is in; sugary yogurt is out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times

item.title: How to Strengthen Your Bones and Reduce Osteoporosis Risk
item.description: A new study predicts hip fractures will nearly double worldwide by 2050. Here’s how to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Hair Loss After Covid: What to Know
item.description: Increased shedding after illness is not unusual. The good news is that it’s most likely temporary.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: At a Michelin-Starred Restaurant, the Ingredients for Romance
item.description: Marley Brown had no appetite for dating when she met Akeel Shah, her colleague at the restaurant SingleThread. But after they bonded over passions for cooking and their careers, love was on the menu.
item.dc:creator: Alix Wall
item.media:credit: Neeta Satam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Akeel Shah and Marley Brown exchange rings at their Sept. 10 wedding ceremony in Belleville, Ill.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
